description.narrative:
Insatsen syftar till att ansluta ca 22 000 hushåll med låga inkomster, och 1 000 småföretag, till elnätet, genom riktade subventioner (riktade för att bidra till jämställdhet och inkluderande tillväxt). Totalt uppskattas 140 000 människor få nytta av insatsen. Vidare ska stödet användas för att utveckla en nationell strategi för elektrifiering, och till att stärka kapaciteten hos nyckelaktörer i den zambiska energisektorn.
Insatsen har tre komponenter: 1. Komponent A innebär resultatbaserade subventioner till nya hushållsanslutningar, samt finansiering för förstärkning och utbyggnad av det nationella eldistributionsnätet. Därmed kommer låginkomsttagare och småföretagare få möjlighet att ansluta till det nationella elnätet. Myndigheten för landsbygdselektrifiering, Rural Electrification Agency REA kommer att ha huvudansvaret för insatsen, samt genomförandet av de olika komponenterna i samarbete med det nationella elbolaget ZESCO .
Komponent B fokuserar på att åtgärder för att underlätta och möjliggöra för privat sektor att investera i elförsörjning utanför det nationella elnätet (off-grid). Det innebär kapacitetsstöd till relevanta myndigheter, samt till att utforma och demonstrera olika finansieringsmodeller för att möjliggöra privata investeringar i mindre elnät (mini-grids) och enskilda solenergisystem.
Komponent C innebär konsult- och kunskapsstöd för att ta fram en nationell strategi för elektrifiering, samt för projektgenomförandet.
Insatsens sammanlagda budget uppskattas till 37,5 MUSD, varav 26,5 MUSD utgörs av ett lån från Världsbanken/IDA. REA och ZESCO uppskattas bidra med egeninsatser motsvarande 2,7 MUSD. De kunder som ansluts förväntas betala totalt ca 0,6 MUSD i anslutningsavgifter. Privata aktörer förväntas investera minst 0,75 MUSD för mini-grids inom ramen för demonstrationskomponenten.
Sidas stöd riktas till Världsbanken genom programmet GPOBA (Global Partnership for Output Based Aid). Motsvarande 7.5 MUSD kommer användas för resultatbaserat stöd/ersättning för anslutningar till elnätet, och för konsulinsatser och kunskapsstöd.
Insatsen bygger på erfarenheter och resultat från tidigare samarbet för landsbygdselektrifiering genom Världsbanken, där tidigare stöd från Sida till GPOBA i Zambia möjliggjorde att 22 700 låginkomsthushåll -ca 120 000 människor - i urbana och periurbana områden anslöts till elnätet, genom att anslutningskostnaden subventionerades.

The intervention aims at enabling about 22,000 low income households and 1,000 micro and small enterprises in rural areas to connect to the electricity grid through the use of targeted subsidies in a gender sensitive and socially inclusive manner. In total 140,000 people are expected to benefit from the project.
The project has three components: 1. The first component will provide Output-Based Aid - subsidies for consumer connections and finance network reinforcements and extensions for on-grid electrification. This is enable the connection of low-income households and micro- and small enterprises to the national grid, for which the REA and the national power utility ZESCO will be the project implementer. 2. The second component will focus on Technical Assistance which will result in the development of a comprehensive National Electrification Strategy as well as timely and efficient Project implementation. 3. The third component of the Project aims at addressing existing regulatory impediments for private sector participation in off-grid electrification, build the needed capacity at key institutions and design, and potentially pilot , financial mechanisms supporting private sector-led electrification through renewable energy mini-grids and stand-alone solar systems. However, this component wont attract any Swedish funds.
The interventions total budget is estimated at US$37.5 million, of which US$26.5 million will be financed by IDA. Estimated in-kind contribution valued at US$2.7 million equivalent will be provided by REA and ZESCO, and estimated US$0.6 million will be co-financed by households and MSEs for on-grid connections and US$0.75 million will be co-financed by private sector developers in off-grid connections. Sida will co-finance the Project through GPOBA with US$7.0 million which will be directed towrds the OBA and relevant TA activities. Further, an additional amount of US$1.0 million equivalent from Sida that will be the cost for administrering the funds, and other off-grid activities by the World bank and the IFC respectively.

To increase access to electricity services by providing approximately 22 000 low-income households and 1000 micro and small enterprises (MSEs) in rural areas of Zambia with access to grid-based electricity services. The supports links to a World Bank funded programme for increased electricity access, in cooperation with Zambia Rural Electrification Agency.
Through the Project, the World Bank will support Zambia to scale up its rural electrification program and increase electricity access in Zambia's targeted rural areas through different modalities for grid extension and off-grid electrification.
The project components are: (i) on-grid electrification access expansion including a connection fee subsidy program and distribution network extension; (ii) off-grid electrification expansion including mini-grid smart subsidy program and off-grid Loan Facility; and (iii) Capacity Building and Project Implementation Support including a National Electrification Strategy.
Swedish support targets component (i) and connection fee subsidies.

description.narrative:
The contribution is a separate component within the World Bank funded Energy Service Access Project (ESAP), implemted by the Rural Electrification Agency, REA. Swedish funding is granted to the Government of Zambia through the global trust fund for results based approaches. (Global Partnership for Results Based Approaches, GRPBA (formerly GPOBA)). The ESAP project and WB IDA loan became effective in June 2018 and continues to make progress on implementation.
This is a second phase of the ESAP project and Sida support to GRPBA, and it also builds on Sida's previous cooperation with Zambia Rural Electrification Agency.
Subsidy connections (Last mile) under the Output Based Aid (OBA) recorded in May 2021,was 28 376 total household connections, providing 147 555 persons with grid access. That is an increase of 12 175 household connections from end of 2019. Of these connections, 31 % are female headed households (down from 36 % in 2019). In addition, 4 460 commercial/SMEs connections were recorded, up with 2 496 connections since 2019. The targets for Sida funding is thus surpassed, although it is expected that additionally 5 000 household connections will be made.
The programme also includes technical assistance, and a major effort is the development of a National Electrification Strategy, for reaching the target of having at least 50 % of the rural population having access to basic energy services by 2030. A geospatial study is prepared to support this work, identifying the most cost-effective ways to reach this target, a combination of fixed grid extensions, minigrids, and solar home systems in different areas of Zambia.
The World Bank rates overall performance until June 2021 to be moderately satisfactory, and the project implementation at REA as satisfactory. The risk rating remains substantial, based on continued materials shortages in the field due to both inconsistencies in ZESCOs materials distribution arrangements; and continued delays in supply of materials sourced mainly from China due to disruptions in supply chains related to the pandemic
